cab.content: SECRET.IMPERIAL WAR CABINET, 1918.Memorandum on Events in India, 1017-18, circulated by theSecretary of State for India.1. The Frontiers. The situation on the'North-West Frontier of India lias been generally satisfactory (lining the past year. It became necessary in June 1917 to undertake military operations against the Mahsud tribesmen of Waziristan, who had been guilty of a series of outrages during the preceding months. The operations were successful, and a settlement was effected with the tribe on the 10th August. Since then, there has been no serious recrudescence of trouble in the North-West Frontier Province ; but difficulties arose in Baluchistan in February 1918 owing to the defiant attitude adopted by the Marris, a tribe occupying the hill country east of Si hi, over the question of the supply oi! recruits to the army. The Harris were subsequently joined by their neighbours the Khetrans, but the trouble did not spread further. Punitive measures were undertaken, and were successfully-concluded by the end of April, a formal settlement being effected with the tribesmen on the 2nd May.On the North-East. Frontier the external borders have been quiet; but towards the end of 1917 disturbances, also traceable to unrest caused by recruiting operations, took place in the Chin Hills district on the Assam-Burma border and among the Kuki tribesmen of the Manipur State and adjoining British territory. Owing to local conditions, the task of dealing with these risings has been one of some difficulty, and the situation, though believed to be well in hand, has not yet been finally cleared up.2. Tibet. The situation on the east frontier of Tibet remained unsatis-factory. Desultory hostilities proceeded between the Tibetans and Chinese throughout the year, and constant appeals for ,assistance reached the Government of India from the former. A British Consular Officer from China is now on his way to the frontier in the hope of arranging a temporary truce.3. Afghanistan and Central Asia. The Amir of Afghanistan maintained his attitude of neutrality throughout the 3rear, and there is no reason to believe that his loyalty to his engagements with, the British Government has been in any way shaken. But the general situation in Central Asia has been profoundly modified by the elimination of Russia from, the war, and the collapse of her authority over her Central Asian subjects. It is impossible to forecast what will ultimately emerge from the present chaos ; but it is quite clear that circumstances have furnished the enemy with a new field for political (and perhaps military) penetration, and a new means of striking at the British position in the East, and the indications are that he intends to take full advantage of them. The situation is engaging the attention of the military and political authorities. In Persia the situation has not developed satisfactorily, and His Majesty's Government have been compelled to incur increased military liabilities both on the eastern and western frontiers of the country. Quite recently tribal disturbances have taken place in South Persia, leading to a conflict with British Indian troops.4. Aden. An important decision was taken in August 1917, when the political control of the Aden region was transferred from the Government of' India to the High Commissioner, Cairo, and the control of military operations from the Government of India to the War Office. The object of the former change was the better co-ordination of all matters affecting the Arabian policy of His Majesty's Government. The Government of India remain responsible for the local administration of the Aden Settlement.SS.022 100 6/18 AA.-EXTERNAL AFFAIRS. 5. Mesopotamia. Sir Percy.Cox, Civil Commissioner in Mesopotamia, pro-ceecled to England in March 1918 to discuss with His Majesty's Government the question of the future administration of Mesopotamia. He is now on His way back. Considerable progress has been made during the year with the settlement, development, iVc, of the occupied territory, a task in which officers of the Government of India have taken a prominent part.B.-WAR CONTRIBUTIONS OF NATIVE STATES OF INDIA.Since the 1st June 1917, the Native States have continued to make generous contributions for the purposes of the War. These contributions have usually taken the form of gifts of money, which Government have been asked to employ, either at discretion or for some specific purpose, e.g., the provision of aeroplanes, motor-boats, or tanks, the maintenance of Indian troops at the front, &c. Such gifts have been received, among others, from the Chiefs of Baroda (5 lakhs, 33,0001.), Indore (5^ lakhs), Bikaner (20,000/..), Nabha (35,0001.), ditch (3,000/, monthly till the end of the war); Patiala, Kotah, Sirohi, Faridkot and Navanagar (I lakh in each case); the Shan States (5,000/,) and the Begum of Bhopal (2,000/.). Half a lakh was contributed by Udaipur, Danta and Bharatpur respectively. The Maharaja Scinclia of Gwalior gave 0,000/." for the benefit of naval officers and. men, and 30,000 francs for Belgian relief.In addition to the above, various munificent offers have, according to reports published in the Press, been made in connection with the War Conference held at Delhi at the end of April last, These include a contri-bution of 100,0007. per annum from the Maharaja Scindia of Gwalior for the duration of the war ; 100,000/. from the Nizam of Hyderabad, for tanks and aeroplanes ; a similar amount from the Gaekwar of Baroda; 20,000/. per annum each, from the Chiefs of Kashmir, Jaipur and Navanagar; three battalions of infantry from Patiala ; another camel transport corps from Chamba, and two additional double companies of Sappers and Miners from Maler Kofi a. Offers to raise new battalions have also been made by Bikaner, Kolhapur, and Dholpur.The miscellaneous contributions included 18 tons of tea from the Prime Minister of Nepal.Apart from the foregoing contributions, the units of Imperial Service Troops on active service are maintained by the Native States at full strength. Recruitment for the Indian Army from the Native States was placed in June 1917 under the direction of the Central Recruiting Board, on which the Maharajas of Gwalior, Bikaner, and Patiala were invited to serve. A scheme has recently been initiated for the formation in Native States for the period of the war of battalions of Indian troops enlistecVmainly in the State concerned, but officered, equipped, paid, and maintained by Govern-ment. The project was favourably received by the Princes present at Delhi during the War Conference, when they were informally consulted.0.-INTERNAL SITUATION, 1917-1018.The economic conditions produced by the AVar, especially the rise of prices of foodstuffs and. cotton goods, have proved a cause of anxiety, but on the whole tranquillity lias been preserved.Political Developments.--From a constitutional point of view the most important, event of the year was the announcement of policy which I made on behalf of His Majesiy's Government in the House of Commons on the 20th August. For convenience the terms of the announcement are reproduced below: "The policy of His Majesty's Government, with which the Government of India are in complete accord, is that of the increasing association of Indians in every branch of the administration, and the- gradual development of self-governing institutions, witn a view to the progressive realisation of responsible Government in India as an integral part of the British Empire. They.have decided that substantial steps in this direction should be taken as soon as possible, and that it is of the highest importance as a preliminary to considering what these steps should be, that there should be a free and informal exchange of opinion between those in authority at home and in India. His Majesty's Government have accordingly decided, with His Majesty's approval, that I should accept the Vieeroy's invitation to proceed to India to discuss these matters with the Viceroy and the Govern-ment of India, to consider with the Viceroy the views of Local Governments, and to receive, with him the suggestions cf representative bodies and others." I would add that progress in this policy can only be achieved by successive stages. The British Government and the Government of India on whom the responsibility lies for the welfare and advancement of the Indian peoples must be the judges of the time and measure of each advance, and they must be guided by the * co-operation received from those upon whom new opportunities of service will thus bo conferred, and by the extent to which it is found that confidence can be reposed in their sense of responsibility."Ample opportunity will be afforded for public discussion of the proposals which will be submitted in due course to Parliament."The announcement was followed in the autumn by my visit to India. The Earl of Donoughinore, Mr. Charles Roberts, ALP. (formerly Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for India), and Sir William Duke (a Member of the Council of India) accompanied me. The results of my mission are embodied in a report signed by the Viceroy and myself, which is shortly to be published. It is sufficient to state here that the report contains recom-mendations designed to give effect to the announcement of the 20th August, and the conclusions therein set forth have been the result of consultation with the Government of India, Local Governments and non-official opinion of all kinds.Internal Situation and the War. On the 2nd April the Prime Minister telegraphed'to the Viceroy appealing for an increase in India's contribution to the war not only in troops, but in equipment of all kinds. The action that is being taken on this appeal is dealt with in other portions of this Memorandum. The importance of the appeal in this connection lies in the action that it enabled the Viceroy to take with a view to combining all classes of Indian society in a heightened effort to increase InchVs war effort in all. directions. I was in India at the time the" appeal was received, and after full discussion with the Viceroy, it was decided to convene a Conference representative of all India at Delhi on the 27th April, by which date I had already left for home. The Conference was presided over by the Viceroy. It, was attended by Members of the Executive Council of the Viceroy, by representatives of the Provincial Governments, by non-official members of the Imperial Legislative Council and about 100 representatives selected by the Provinces from all shades of political opinion. Sixteen Ruling Princes were also present. The Conference, which was the first of its kind ever held in India, passed the following Resolution in response to a gracious message sent by His Majesty : " The Conference of Ruling Princes and representative leaders of all classes of the people of India assembled at Delhi to-day have authorised me (i.e., the Viceroy), in a resolution passed unanimously, to convey to His Majesty the King-Emperor an expression of India's dutiful and loyal response to his gracious message and an assurance . of her determination to continue to do her duty to her utmost capacity in the great crisis through which the Empire is passing. India is determined that His Majesty's confidence that she will not fail the Empire in its hour of crisis shall be fully justified and that man-power and resources of the country shall be utilised to the greatest possible extent in the cause for which Empire is lighting."This message embodies the keynote of the Conference. The Viceroy reports that the meeting exhibited a cordial desire to furnish further assistance to the Empire, and it is hoped as a result of the enthusiasm stimulated by the gathering and the measures to be taken in accordance with the resolutions passed by it to obtain half a million.recruits for the Army during the ensuing year. The Government of India have expressed the opinion that the object of the Conference, which was to enlighten India generally on the situation and to enlist the co-operation of prominent men of all classes in the measures necessary to increase-her war effort-, was achieved. The continuance of energetic recruitment upon a voluntary basis and the formation of publicity and employment bureaux were approved. The immediate constitution of Provincial Committees was recommended for the purpose of co-operating with, the Munitions Board and other authorities in furthering economy of railway traffic and the encouragement of consumption locally of local products, and with a view to controlling supplies and promoting the immediate development of a programme for the construction of shipping, and the production of foodstuffs and war requirements.The Ruling Princes present at the Conference renewed their assurances of unswerving loyalty to the King and of attachment to His Imperial Majesty, and their determination to continue unabated to the utmost of their abilities and resources their efforts for the successful prosecution of the war.Civil Services in the War. It is worth noting that while duty in India, which itself is of real importance during war, has necessarily absorbed the bulk of the civil services, no less than 340 civil officers of the Indian Services have been lent in this country either to the Army or to civil depart-ments, while many civil servants have been released in India for military duties. Indian officials have also been able to give material help to the United States authorities in the detection and punishment of anti-Ally conspiracies in America.D.--THE MILITARY ASSISTANCE GIVEN BY INDIA IN THE PROSECUTION OF THE WAR DURING 1917-18, AND THAT CONTEMPLATED DURING- 19.18-19.Attached is a copy of a memorandum on the military assistance givenby India in' the prosecution of the Appendix I. wai.( conjpiled jn Marc]l 1917) and laidbefore the last Imperial War Conference. It shows what had been done up to March 1917, and attached, are copies of telegrams between the Secretary of State and the Government of India, which were also presented to the Conference, showing the programme of recruitment and formation of new units for the ensuing year .191.7-18.Operations, 1917-18.Mesopotamia. Daring the past year Indian troops have continued to form the bulk of the force operating in this theatre ; all the Divisions being-Indian except the 13th, which was despatched from Egypt to Mesopotamia when the troops, under General Townshend, were besieged in Kut-el-Amara.Egypt, There has been a very considerable increase in the number of Indian troops employed in this theatre. The Indian Cavalry portion of the 4th and 5th Cavalry Divisions, who had been serving in France since 1914, have been, sent to Egypt, Two complete "Indian Infantry Divisions" have been added to the Force, and four British. Divisions are now in process of conversion to "Indian Divisions," the necessary Indian Battalions being sent for the purpose of relieving British units for service in France.N.B. The main difference between a British and an Indian Division is in the Infantry. The latter includes only three British Battalions, with ten Indian Battalions.France. As stated above, the Indian Cavalry have been withdrawn and despatched to Egypt,Approximately, 40,000 Indian labourers have been sent to this theatre,, but the majority were enlisted for one year only, and these are now in. process of repatriation to India. A large number of Indian artillery personnel have arrived, and are being employed with divisional, ammunition columns in order to relieve the British ranks formerly employed with these units. The conversion, is being effected gradually as men can. bp raised, trained in India, and despatched to France.East Africa. Practically all the Indian troops have been withdrawn from this theatre. Salonika.-Only a few Indian units (artillery and transport) are employed in this theatre, and these have been maintained during the year.Aden. The control of operations at Aden was taken over by the War Office-in August 1917, but the Force has continued to be maintained by India.India. During the past .12 months operations have been undertaken on the North-West Frontier against the Mahsuds (May to August 1917), and against the Morris (March to April: 191.8). In both cases punitive forces advanced rapidly into the tribal country, with the result that the tribes submitted to the terms dictated by the Government of India. Disturbances have also occurred in the Chin districts of Burma. Actually, about 285,000 coni-batants were enlisted, and consequently the formation of a further .33 Battalions of Infantry, and 20 Squadrons of Cavalrywas authorised.In April 1018 the formation of a further 28 battalions was sanctioned, and, as they were urgently required in Egypt, 22 of them were formed by taking companies from Indian units already in the field, the men so with-drawn being replaced in their original units by drafts of young soldiers with not less than six months' training from India. The remaining six battalions are being formed in India.This very considerable increase in the strength of the,Indian Army necessitated a reorganising of recruiting methods and a widening of the field of operations so as to exploit classes other than those recruited under normal conditions.The Central Recruiting Board was established in 1917 under the Adjutant-General to deal with the question, and Provincial Recruiting-Boards were formed by all the Local Governments. A strong Indian element was included in the Provincial Boards, which, work in the closest touch with the local civil authorities.Idle broadening of the basis of recruitment may be divided into : (1) Recruitment of races whose martial traditions have faded through long years of peace and who had ceased to be recruited for the Indian Army.(2) Increased recruitment of races normally recruited in small numbers only for the Indian Army, but who have done well in the Field during the present war.The method of work which has been adopted by the new organisation is for the Central Board to inform the Provincial Boards of the number of recruits, combatant and non-combatant, it is hoped to obtain monthly from each Province. The method of obtaining the allotted quota is left to the Provincial Boards, who are in close touch with local conditions.It must be understood, of course, that the Central Board restricts the recruitment of combatants to classes who have proved their worth in the field or who possess martial traditions. In the latter case the normal procedure is to enlist, say, one Company, and from this Ho form an opinion on the possibilities of the class under trial.Indian Labour Corps.In order to economise shipping, recruiting has now been limited to men willing to serve for the duration of the war, and companies from these drafts, together with men under 12 months' contract williug to sign on for further engagement, are being formed in France.Indian Artillery Personnel.About 20,000 Indian ranks have been recruited, trained, and despatched to France, Egypt, and Salonica, where they are being emplo.yed to replace British personnel with Ammunition Columns.Indian Defence Force.Prior to the war a volunteer force existed in India; the units, however, were only liable to serve in their own locality in case of disturbances, aud their training left much to be desired. This volunteer force was converted in 1917 into the "Indian Defence Force," in which service is compulsory for all Europeans and Anglo-Indian British subjects. The training and discipline of this force is far more thorough than was the case with tbe former volunteers and the liability for service more extensive. There is an Indian section of the force recruited by the voluntary enrolment of Indians. The /total strength Is rather more than 50,000 men as against 40,000 of the former volunteers.Munitions.The Indian Munitions Board was organised at the beginning of 191.7, and undertook: its formal duties as a Department of the Government of India on 1st April of that year for the purpose of concentrating attention on the expansion of Indian sources of munitions supply, or relieving other Departments of overlapping duties relative to war supplies, of preventing injurious competition in buying between different Government Departments, and of aiding the British Ministry of Munitions by centralising scrutiny, and by standardising the principles which regulate the disposal in India of applications from India for plant and stores of military significance.This new Department has taken over control of the existing ordnance factories in India, and considerable extensions are now being made to certain of them, with a view to increasing the daily output of gun ammu-nition from 5,000 to 25,000 complete rounds. An acetone factory is also . nearly complete, and. suggestions are now being made for the manufacture of machine guns. This, however, is only a small part of the work of the Munitions Board. A great deal has been done to develop the manufacture in India of military requirements other than guns and ammunition, such as boots, saddlery, serge and drill for clothing, kit bags, brushes, knives, forks, -spoons, and many other articles which formerly were imported from home.The result of this has been that India is rapidly becoming self-sup port-ing in many military necessities, such as clothing, leather goods, blankets and textiles generally, and supplies nearly all requirements of the Mesopotamia Force and many articles to Egypt and East Africa, thus effecting considerable economy in shipping and relieving the strain on home manufactures.Programme for further Expansion of the Indian Armyduring 1918-19.On 2nd April 1918 the Prime Minister sent a message to the Government of India asking them to consider how they could increase their efforts towards the successful prosecution of the war. As previously stated, this message arrived when I was in India, and after discussion with the Viceroy a Conference was assembled at Delhi to consider all aspects of the question. On loth May the Government of India telegraphed that they hoped to enlist half a million men during the 12 months ending 1st June 1919. Should this proposal be accepted, together with certain other proposals calculated to stimulate recruiting, and carried out it may be of interest to note that the normal pre-war recruiting figure for the Iudian Army of about 15,000 men per annum will have been increased to 500,000, or for every man formerly enlisted over 33 will now have to be obtained. A large number of these men will, of course, be required to provide reinforcements for the numerous Indian contingents serving overseas and to cover wastage among units in India, but after making a liberal allowance for the above, it is considered that the following new units can be raised for Imperial Service : 7 Squadrons Cavalry, 14 Batteries Mountain Artillery, 91 Battalions Infantry, 21 Companies Sappers and Miners,7 Divisional Signal Companies.In other words,, this programme will provide the necessary Indian man power for seven Divisions less Field Artillery and certain ancillary troops. The Army Council have not yet (3rd June) stated officially that they will be in a position, to arm, equip, and employ the new units as above.There are still a number of units from the past yeaFs programme which -are not yet on service overseas, but which will become fit for the field during the current year.. The present programme for their employment is (1) complete the conversion of four British Divisions in Egypt to "Indian. Divisions," and (2) similarly to commence conversion of four British Divisions at Salon ica to "Indian Divisions," (3) strengthen the Field Army in India. It is hoped to complete this programme during 1918, when the "Forces serving in Mesopotamia, Egypt, Salonica, and Aden will consist mainly of Indian troops drawing reinforcements from India, thus relieving, to a great extent, the calls on British lighting man power.Grant of Commissions to Indiana. In the summer of 1917 the War Cabinet decided that the bar that, had hitherto prevented Indians from obtaining commissioned rank in His Majesty's Army should be removed, and in accordance with this decision commissions were conferred, on nine Indians who had rendered distinguished service in the war. Proposals are now under consideration for the grant of a number of temporary commissions to Indians for the period of the war in connection with the increased effort that India will contribute towards the prosecution of: the war in 1918-19.E.-SUPPLY OF FOODSTUFFS AXI) MATERIAL FOR PURPOSESOF THE WAR.A year ago a memorandum was laid before the Conference describing . the extent to which the Allies were dependent on India for commoditiesessential for the prosecution of the Appendix II. war, and it was explained that had theresources of India not been available the difficulties of the war would have been enormously increased, if, indeed, its prosecution on the present scale would have been at all possible.During the past year the help so given has been continued, and large quantities of essential commodities have been supplied mainly under State control or by State purchase. In many cases, such as manganese ore, wolfram, saltpetre, mica,, shellac, jute, jute goods and castorseed, India is the sole or main source of supply ; in other cases, such as raw and tanned hides, wheat, rice, tea, and oilseeds, Iudia's contribution represents a substantial portion of the total world supply.Shortage of shipping has necessarily restricted the material aid that can be rendered by India, but war conditions have created special, cliffi-culties of another kind connected with the financing of exports, and these are now operating in the same direction. The resources of the Exchange Banks have, however, been mobilised with the object of giving preferential finance to exports of national importance, and it is some indication of the importance of these exports that, in 1917, out of a total export trade of 150,000,0007.., they accounted for nearly 88,000,0007. This was the value of exports of direct war importance, but many other exports, such, for example, as jute goods required for the movement of the crops of other countries, are no less important, and it would be within the mark to place the value of Indian, war exports at 1.10,000,0007.Numerous measures of State control and State purchase have been adopted, each adapted to the trade concerned and each designed to * ensure adequate supplies to the Allies at a reasonable price. Profiteering has been restricted, and in some cases, such as wheat, oilseeds, and hides, produce is obtainable at prices much lower than those ruling in other markets.Some of the more "important commodities are dealt with below very briefly: Wheat and other Grains. Indian wheat is for the most part required -for the Mediterranean Allies and Egypt, and in 1917 1,383,838 tons, of the value of .11,836,5217., were purchased and exported by the Government of India on behalf of the Royal Commission on Wheat Supplies. The special measures taken last autumn to increase production resulted in the planting of the record area of 34,088,000 acres, and to ensure the harvesting of the crop recruiting was temporarily suspended in the Punjab, the most important wheat province. The crop will, it is estimated, yield an exportable surplus of 2,000,000 tons, and as it is highly important to avoid any inflation of internal prices purchases will he made by" the Royal Commission at an average price (certainly less than 50s. per quarter) much lower than that riding in other markets.In the past year 700,01)0 tons of other grains were supplied for military purposes in Egypt and Salonica, and India also supplies the grain required by the Forces in Mesopotamia, the Persian Gulf, Aden and East Africa, rice and flour lor Egypt, and flour for Salonica.Rice and Beans. Arrangements have been made for the Government purchase of 100,000 tons monthly at a favourable price, mainly for our European Allies, and this quantity, approximately, is now being shipped. Freight and finance difficulties may, however, bring about a reduction of this programme, and these causes will also operate to reduce the jmrchases of Rangoon beans.Tea-In 191.7 over 200,000,000 lbs. (0,757,9691.) were exported to the United Kingdom, and towards the close of the year a contract was entered into between the Food Controller and the Indian producers for the supply of all the tea required for the troops and for the civil population of this country. This contract has recently been renewed and the new contract involves the purchase during the next J 2 months of about 250,000,000 lbs., worth, roughly, 10,000,0001Wolfram, Chrome, and Manganese Ores.-The vigorous measures taken by the Indian Government to increase the production of wolfram ores have borne fruit, and, against a pre-war export of 1,700 tons, 4,839 tons (735,08,U.) were exported in 1917 to the United Kingdom, at a fixed price, for the manufacture of tungsten. Of chrome ore 9,057 tons (against 1,296 in 1915) were exported. India is practically tho only source of supply of manganese ore to this country, and in addition to supplying 354,276 tons (431,303/.) to the United Kingdom, considerable quantities (127,348 tons) were exporfed to the Allies.Saltpetre. The trade is under the strictest control, and with the exception of small quantities supplied to the Colonies the whole production is exported at-fixed' prices to the United Kingdom and Allied countries for the manufacture of gunpowder. Last year 515,374 cwt. (677,8561.) were exported almost entirely to this country, which for this essential commodity relies solely on India as a source of supply.Tanned and Raw Hides and Tanning Materials. In addition to the large quantities of leather required in India for the manufacture of army boots .and accoutrements, this country depends very largely on Indian tanned hides, which provide upper leather for 60 per cent, of the boots manufactured. The whole exportable surplus is reserved and purchased for the War Office; tanning is under strict control, and the tanning of skins has been prohibited in order to encourage hide tanning. The war has brought about a marked development and improvement of Indian tanning, and in 1917 the value of the tanned hides exported was 3,346,185/.Paw hides, though less important, are still, in. view of the enormous demand and the shortage of supplies, necessary to the tanners of this country, and it is estimated that Indian raw hides supply from 5 to 10 per cent, of the upper leather manufactured here.The exportable surplus is purchased by the Government of India on behalf of His Majesty's and the Italian Governments, and last year 413,138 cwt. (2,151,404/,) were exported to the United Kingdom and Italy.Large quantities of tanning materials are also supplied, and in .1917 778,206 cwt. (294,241/.) of myrabolams alone were exported to this country.Mica. The trade is under the strictest control, and to ensure that suitable grades of mica are reserved for the Ministry of Munitions practically all mica is shipped to this country for selection. In 1917, 58,785 cwts. (474,744/.) were exported to the United Kingdom.Shellac. In accordance with the Resolutions passed by Parliament in the early stage of the war, India has continued to contribute-towards the cost of the Indian Expeditionary Forces a sum equivalent to what the ordinary expenditure on the troops sent out of the country would have been had they remained in India. Tho net amount so contributed in 1917-18 was about 4,250,000/., and it is worth noting that as by.Statute the revenues of India are not applicable, without the consent of Parliament, to defraying the expenses of any military operation carried on beyond the Indian frontier by troops on the Indian establishment, fresh Resolutions of Parliament would he necessary to increase the share of the cost at present borne by India.But the figure just mentioned only represents a small part of Iudia!s military expenditure. In 1917-18 this amounted to about 28,750,000/., as com-pared with an average of about 19,700,000/. in the years immediately preceding the war. This increased outlay has been occasioned partly by military measures required for the better protection of India and partly by active operations on the North-West Frontier, to which reference has already been made. In addition India is sharing with His Majesty's Government expenditure in Persia of a military or semi-military character.General Financial Situation. Reference has already been made to the vast quantities of commodities of all sorts that are being supplied by India for the purposes of the war. The purchase of these commodities has in the main to be financed in India. In addition the Government of India are financing, against repayment in England, the expenditure in. the Pi eld of the-troops in Mesopotamia and East Africa, the cost of the food and equipment, &c. supplied to these forces from India and to the Indian troops in other theatres. The requirements are on a continually increasing scale, and in 1917-18 the expenditure so undertaken on behalf of the Imperial Government amounted to no less than 60,000,000/." The financing of this vast expenditure has entailed the most serious drain on the currency resources of the Government of India, and though every effort has been made to obtain silver from any available quarter, and to popularise the circulation of currency notes (efforts which, considering the circumstances, have been far from unsuccessful), the currency situation of the Government of India has always been most anxious throughout the year and on occasions critical. The world supplies of silver have been short, and the world demand abnormally heavy. In 1916-17 and 1917-18 India imported silver to the value of 29,000,000/. sterling. Other measures were also taken to increase the utility of the available resources for financing exports of war importance. First the portion of the Paper Currency Reserve that may be held or vested in British securities was largely increased. Secondly measures were taken to ensure that, so far as possible, the available means of financing exports from India should be devoted to commodities necessary for the prosecution of the war. But these measures were insufficient to meet the needs of the case, and recourse has been had to the assistance of the United States Government, A representative of the India Office was deputed to America, and the special features of,the Indian situation were explained to the United States Govern-ment. India is a country where the average of individual wealth is very small and it has for generations been accustomed to an abundant supply of metallic money. The Government of India were convinced that if they could not meet the demands on their treasuries for rupees there would be a financial panic which might seriously jeopardise their ability lo obtain the supplies of goods required for the war. These considerations impressed the United States Government aud they have readily responded to the request that they should sell to the Allies a large quantity of silver held in their Mint reserve. A special Act of Congress was required for this purpose. It was passed last April and the first shipment of silver to India under it took place in May. This measure will, it is hoped, tide the Government of India over their immediate difficulties, but it will be realised that the efforts made by India to finance the requirements of the Allied Governments have been attended with extreme difficulty and with much danger to the currency system, a danger which has not; yet been entirely surmounted, and which has compelled the Government to consider whether the demands on India cannot be restricted to some extent in the future.Direct Contribution by India towards the Costs of the War.The outstanding event of 1917-18 was the carrying into effect of the Resolution of both Houses of Parliament passed on 14th March .1917, under which, authority was given to the Government of India to make a direct con-tribution of 100,000,0007. towards the cost of the war. The intention was to raise as much as possible of this sum by loan in India, and to liquidate the balance by the Government of India, taking over the required amount of British war debt, meeting the interest thereon and gradually discharging the principal. In accordance with this arrangement a War Loan was raised in India in 1917-18. The response far exceeded all expectations, for, whereas before the war a loan of 4,000,0007. would have been regarded as exceptional, a sum of 36,000,0007. was received, and was in due course transferred to the Imperial, Government, and at a later date in the same year about 30,000,0007. was raised by the Government of India in the form of Treasury Bills for the purpose of financing war expenditure in India. The applications for the War Loan from all classes were "most satisfactory, Large subscriptions were also received from the principal Native States. The Government of India state that the splendid response to their loan appeal was due in great measure to the patriotic efforts of Provincial and District War Loan Committees working under the auspices of the Heads of Provincial Governments,, as also to the. cordial co-operation of the Presidency Banks.In estimating the meaning to India of this contribution, which forms a landmark in her history, it has to be borne in mind that she is a poor and backward country, lacking many elementary advantages of civilisation which England and the Self-Governing Dominions have long possessed. It is not a case of denying herself luxuries, but of severely restricting expenditure on education, sanitation, and industries. The contribution represents nearly two years of her net revenue as it stood at the beginning of the war.Prospect for 1918-19. The Present Situation.The course of events described.above has denuded India of the bulk of its troops and has drained off the cream of its armed forces, thus leaving it with the bare minimum required to maintain internal order aud to defend the frontier. It is not too much to say that at the present moment the military security of India rests largely on a well-established military prestige and on the trust reposed in a just and paternal administration.The military forces left in India are not only numerically deficient but also of inferior quality. The British troops are largely composed of Territorial and Garribon Regiments, which naturally are not equal to the old " regulars " withdrawn from India. As regards Indian troops, owing to the constant demands for reinforcements to make good the wastage of war, regiments in. India have been depleted of many of their best men. Some regiments have given from 200-400 men each as drafts for the forces at the seat of war, and in consequence are short of trained soldiers and have an undue pro-portion of recruits and elderly reservists unfit for any strenuous service. They are also very deficient in experienced officers.The Government of India have now undertaken to release 12 Terri-torial Battalions from India for service elsewhere, as' well as to relieve the 13th Division in Mesopotamia by troops from India. They are also arranging to expand three battalions now in Egypt to a strength of six battalions. In place of the above the War Office have engaged to send five more Garrison battalions to India and also to return an Indian battalion from Ceylon.In order to carry out the above engagements the Indian. Government, has had to take steps to embody 1 \ battalions of Volunteers and raise 16. new battalions of Indian Infantry. They have also passed an Act imposing the obligation of military service on the European population.It is unnecessary, to state in detail the exact number of units of all kinds remaining in India, but the aggregate strength of the Army may be taken at about a quarter of a million men, of which nearly one-third are British. In addition to the above, there are about 11,000 Imperial Service troops and 46,000 Volunteers, including Volunteer Reserves. The strength of the Volunteer Force will doubtless be augmented under the recent enactment, but to what extent is not yet known. The question may arise in the course of the Conference whether the troops in India are sufficient to cope both with Frontier troubles and with the internal situation. A few remarks on that subject are therefore added.The essential factor from a purely Indian point of view is the defence of the North-West Frontier, for on that largely depends the internal peace of India. On the whole, the position on the Frontier is at present reassuring, but there is undoubtedly a certain amount of unrest, more particularly on the Waziri and Mohmand borders. There are mutteriugs of "Jehad" all along the Afghan marches, and though the Amir is believed to be thoroughly loyal to us, that safeguard, depends on his life. At any moment he may be assassinated or die a natural death, in which case we might expect an upheaval in Afghanistan. Should this occur the whole Frontier might possibly be in a blaze. The imperative necessity for a watchful policy and preparation for instant action is therefore obvious. From the comnience-ment of the war this necessity lias been fully recognised, and Lord Crewe in 1914 authorised the maintenance of three Divisions and a Cavalry Brigade on a mobilised footing in addition to the troops comprising the Independent Brigades at Kohat, Bannu and the Derajat.If Afghanistan should proclaim, war, all the tribes from the Black Mountain to the Takht-i-Suliinan would be up, but they can be, held and defied provided that the Landi Kotal position is occupied in sufficient -force in good time.As regards the other main lines of approach, the line through Bajaur and Swat is securely barred by the strong positions at Chakdara and the Malakand, while the hill country to east and west of the Malakand route can be effectively watched by small columns near Rustam and Shabkadr respec-tively. If the Afridis were to throw in their lot with the Afghans, and thus menace communications with Landi Kotal through the Khaibar, it would be necessary to occupy Bazaar. The other route from the Afridi country down the Dara Valley can be "easily closed by a small column operating from Peshawar.The next line of approach to India is the Kurram. This is effectually closed by snow at the Shutargardan from Christmas till the end of March or often much later. Small columns at Thai, Mi ran Shah, Bannu, and Ton It should be able to deal effectually with raiders from Khost or Waziristan. The Gomal Pass has in the past been frequently utilised as a line of invasion by various Asiatic conquerors, but modern conditions, coupled with our flanking position at Quetta, should preclude the use of this line by any Afghan army at the present time,The next and most southerly line of invasion is that from Kandahar through Quetta. Our position at Quetta, if adequately defended, is one of the strongest imaginable, and a Division is ample to deal with any Afghan and tribal forces likely to attack in this direction, at all events under present conditions.This brief survey of the frontier is incomplete without some remarks regarding Chitral. Chitral would be isolated; the troops there for six months are cut off by snow from both Kashmir and the direct route over the Lowari Pass through Dir. If the Chitralis were so ill-advised as to join in a "Jehad," the situation for the Chitral garrison would be one of extreme peril, but this is a risk that would have to be taken. It is improbable, how-ever, that the Chitralis would join their hereditary enemies, the Afghans.Apart from a possible Afghan invasion, the only storm centres are the Mohmand country and Waziristau. As regards the Mohmands, a blockade can always be easily established, and much further trouble need not be * anticipated. Waziristan is always a sore spot and petty raids and ambuscades are a constant source of annoyance, but the Waziris are incapable of taking any formidable offensive, though their hostility would doubtless result in locking up troops in the Derajat, Baunu, and Tochi areas. The Afridis have always hitherto been considered a danger, and as they, together with the Orakzais, include a considerable number of well-armed men trained as soldiers in the Indian Army, they doubtless are not to be despised as an enemy; but the very fact that they know our power and their own inability to withstand it in the plains produce a restraining influence.SS 622 F From Secretary of Stale to Viceroy, Army Department, -' 2Si/i. As these arrangements have only recently been introduced returns are not available, but it may be taken that, exclusive of the large quantities supplied to Mesopotamia and Egypt, about 40,000 50,000 tons are being shipped monthly to Mediterranean ports.Ordinarily, India imports large quantities of coal from the United Kingdom, Natal, Japan and Australia, mainly as bunkers for steamers leaving Bombay. These supplies are now necessarily restricted, and on India has fallen the burden not only of making good the deficiency, but of providing largely increased quantities to neighbouring coaling stations (Colombo, Singapore and Sebang) for the Admiralty and the mercantile marine. The Australian strike has added to the difficulties, which have only been overcome by the severe restriction of the use of first-class coal by Indian factories and railways.The foregoing account which, as already stated, does not deal Avitli the assistance given in the campaigns in Mesopotamia, Egypt and East Africa, is sufficient to justify the claim that had the agricultural and mineral resources of India not been made available the prosecution of the war in Europe on its present scale would not have been possible, and it is perhaps unnecessary to add to the length of this memorandum by describing in any detail the assistance given in such commodities as teak for the Admiralty, raw silk, hemp and coir, tea for the troops, opium for the manufacture of morphia, rubber, oil cakes, skins and petroleum. While these are of direct national value they do" .not bulk so largely as those already described, and in most cases supplies from other sources are available.
